I doubt this would keep most criminals from offending.  And finally the novel covers the topic of persona backups and copying.  This is a concept that seems misrepresented by many science fiction authors.  A copy (or backup) is just that.  Once the original is gone (dead) they can't come back to life as a copy. B002ZG980U|3.0|\\"Inception\\" has elements of both \\"Memento,\\" which launched the whiz kid Christopher Nolan's film career, and \\"The Prestige,\\" which is Nolan's most complex and subtle, interesting and entertaining, cerebral and provocative achievement to date.      Like \\"Memento,\\" \\"Inception\\" is concerned with how the mind works, how it chooses to gain or lose control over itself.  \\"Memento\\" was about memories, those crucial building blocks of our identity, and \\"Inception\\" is about dreams, which the movie argues is fundamental to how we think and behave.  (Extraction is about looking for locked-away memories, and inception is about implanting a small idea that then grows until like a virus it subsumes everything.)      Like \\"The Prestige,\\" \\"Inception\\" is a complicated maze.  In fact, it is like the dreamworld in which it inhabits, a multi-layered maze, with no start, no exit, and no direction.  Its precious complexity, a Nolan trademark, is ultimately the film's undoing, as while the film clearly entrances it does not hold and capture, and ultimately its idea fails to implant itself:  Nolan's inception has failed.  Both \\"The Machinist\\" and \\"Mulholland Drive\\" are far more fascinating (and, I believe from a neuroscientist's point of view, accurate) meditations on dreams, dreaming, and dreamers.          Why the film fails is that Nolan does not establish anything concrete in the film, meaning that the entire film feels like a concocted dream.  There is a section which is meant to be \\"reality\\" but the acting is so bad, the editing so fast, the plot so incredible (everything so conveniently falls into place) that it fails to anchor us, and so we just float away.  There are many contradictions (or in Nolan parlance \\"paradoxes) in the film, and that's how Nolan likes it.  I think Nolan was going after the effect of having questioned everything about the film the audience now begins to question everything about their reality.    But, uh, what's the point of that?      There is no doubt thatNolan is one of the most talented and definitely the most cerebral of our directors today.  But there's nothing substantive or particularly intellectual about his films:  they're all just intricate and intriguing puzzles, meant to entertain and challenge the mind -- but there's just no greater meaning under the surface.  So \\"The Inception\\" team dig deeper and deeper into our minds, and all they see is either a vast blanket of snow or a great expansive empty ocean.      The best thing about Nolan as a director is that he knows how to use good actors.  Both Christian Bale and Hugh Jackman were terrific in \\"The Prestige,\\" and Leonardo DiCaprio shines more under Nolan than under Scorcese.  DiCaprio can be juvenile and irritating under Scorcese (which is probably how Scorcese wants it) but DiCaprio is captivating and sympathetic in this movie.      \\"Inception\\" is a fundamentally flawed concept and plot, but given the mediocrity that is Hollywood nowdadays it's better than most things out there.
0553805371|5.0|Disclaimer: I am reviewing an advance copy that I received for free through the Vine program.<br /><br />What a wonderful book! It is short (less than 200 pages) and very readable, and makes some excellent points (though perhaps there are a few weird out-on-a-limb subjective things, like saying that philosophy is dead... I guess one would have to ask what the authors meant by philosophy, and what they meant by dead).<br /><br />Good stuff, about \\"model-dependent\\" observations and theories... maybe if you sum your Feynmann diagrams in a \\"top-down\\" fashion instead of \\"bottom up\\", you get results which can be interpreted as showing that the \\"future influences the past\\" .... all depends on your model and observations ...<br /><br />Definitely swings for the fences, goes for the big questions, about the big picture. Good discussion of the anthropic principle (both 'weak' and 'strong' especially in light of M theory). Basically we're here and we observe things, so of course this particular universe, this particular set of natural physical laws/constants, this galaxy, solar system, planet etc. are supportive of our kind of life and evolved intelligence (but there are probably lots of others too, which are NOT so amenable to life like us, so we're just like 1 possible outcome, out of 10 to the 500th power possibilities).<br /><br />The book pulls together a summary of recent advances in cosmological theory for the armchair reader (notably M-theory), explaining that with gravity added to quantum mechanics, that just may be a sufficient setting for everything -- Thus we might finally have an explanation for how the entire universe has popped into being, as something from nothing, with no added ingredients required, no prime mover, no intention, etc. (this is the part that has religious nuts all worked up, because it's just eliminated one final hiding place for their \\"god of the gaps\\")<br /><br />To paraphrase from memory without cheating and looking in the book again, basically if I remember correctly, locally quantum-mechanical space time is very stable, with virtual particles not lasting very long, cancelling each other out; but globally, over the entire multiverse, with gravity at relativistic scales in the mix, it becomes unstable, enough that universes, like our own, can indeed just come into existence.tum-mechanical space time is very stable, with virtual particles not lasting very long, cancelling each other out; but globally, over the entire multiverse, with gravity at relativistic scales in the mix, it becomes unstable, enough that universes, like our own, can indeed just come into existence.
0452295548|3.0|I found this book quite annoying. It is relatively short (177 pages), with largish type, but it is still quite repetitive, so there only seemed to be enough actual material here for a magazine article. The description of her actual experience of the stroke was interesting, though it is a little hard to believe that she actually thought all those things as her brain was shutting down. Her description of herself before the stroke is also off-putting--the Singin' Scientist? Performing little jingles about donating your brain to the Harvard Brain Bank when you die? Wow, embarrassingly dorky. And the author's photo in the back of the book, showing her wrapped in her mother's arms? Also embarrassingly dorky.<br /><br />The narrative part of the book is very difficult to fully believe. After having a major brain hemorrhage, she is sent home to recover without having the blood clot removed and the AVM repaired. She has the capacity of an infant, but 4 months later, she somehow manages to give a 20-minute speech at a college, even though she had lost the ability to read? Seriously? And she arranges her hair in a comb-over to hide the 9\\" scar? Oh I'm sure no one noticed a thing!<br /><br />But hey, she's a Ph.D., she works at Harvard, so she must be a brilliant and insightful person, right? If so, she apparently thinks the rest of us are morons, because the book talks down to us, explaining how to pronounce hemorrhage and telling us over and over not to yell at people who have had a stroke.<br /><br />The rest of the book is a mixture of advice to caregivers and stroke survivors and a paean to the wonders of life without  left-brain rationality. Well no, the left brain is valuable too, but the right brain is sooo much better. All peace and joy and compassion and oneness with the universe. And who would have thought it? It turns out that what the right brain really likes is everything New Agers have been selling us--including vanilla scented candles and harmonic CDs. You don't need to have a stroke to try this out. Simple meditation will enable you to access a more right-brained reality.<br /><br />The appendix at the back of the book gives some idea how dorky this book is: Ten Assessment Questions (under the heading Recommendations for Recovery):<br /><br />1. Have you had my eyes and ears checked to make sure you know that I can see and hear?<br />2. Can I discriminate color?<br />...<br />7. Can I access my food? Can my hands open the containers? Do I have the strength and dexterity to feed myself?<br /><br />Oh come on! How could anyone think that those caring for a stroke survivor forgot to find out whether the person is able to access food or not? It's hard to tell whether she is patronizing us, or whether she is really just not making any sense.<br /><br />If you have no knowledge about brain hemispheres and no understanding of what happens in a stroke, and if you have a high tolerance for la-di-da isn't life wonderful stuff, you may like this book. But don't expect too much, going in.e to try this out. Simple meditation will enable you to access a more right-brained reality. But don't expect too much, going in.

B001TK3XPE|5.0|Having worked with the hearing impaired, I found this story of a aging man with high frequency hearing loss a howl.  It so aptly described the pains and pleasures of hearing loss and the tendency to live in one's own world, creating sentences from what must have been said, rather than actually understanding what was said.  This was a small story without major drama, the sort of drama we create contrived from faulty perceptions, imaginings and lapses.  The characters were deftly drawn, the relationships real, the prose was fresh and amusing.
B003XURDAY|4.0|There are three different versions of Bladerunner, which can create a lot of confusion for people.  Each version is edited differently, with different scenes, different effects, and even a different story.    The most entertaining, intelligent, visually beautiful, definitive version is Ridley Scott's director's cut, also known as \\"Bladerunner: The Final Cut\\".  That version is available on remastered DVD so don't spend your money on anything else.
0393325172|5.0|Patrick O'Brian approaches the time period with an unusual degree of mastery of the time period. The Hornblower series along with some of the other more generally known period set naval series smack too much of contrived fiction and at times seem to work too hard to convince their audiences that they are literate in 19th century English life, with an obvious emphasis on the workings of a frigate or ship of the line. Not for a single moment is O'Brian's grasp of the period called into question. His classic portrayels of men from the both the upper and lower decks is as convincing as it is authentic. Preserved Killick, Captain Aubrey's erstwhile and abusive steward is a perfect example of O'Brians effortless capture of a forgotten sort of character. Without having to resort to creative spelling to carry the sense of his dialogue and voice, O'Brian is able to utilize word choice to carry Killick's screeching, whining tone clearly to us, the reader today.     Additionally the conduct of battles and actions, spread across multiple theatres of the Napolenonic Wars all combine to lend a healthy dose of believability to the writing of O'Brian. With an unshakeable grasp of naval terms and concepts, the importance of tactiacal maneuvering before an engagement, and the steadfast reliance on rapid, accurate gunfire, O'Brian succeeds where others have failed. The self doubt and at times self loathing of Hornblower finds no place in the character of Jack Aubrey, the unshakeable captain who is on a lee shore when he is... on shore. At sea he demonstrates time and again his grasp of captaincy and leadership. These characteristics are only aided by his erstwhile companion, confidant, and associate, Stephen Maturin. Surgeon and oftentime secret agent. Their friendship serves to add the needed human touch to a series that could so quickly be sidelined by a succession of overly dramatized naval engagements and intrigue.     Throughout this series, if you develop a love for them as strong as that which i have, You too will find yourself yearning for more. It is such a shame that O'Brian passed away before capping the series, but i feel blessed to have as many books, all of equal quality, that he saw fit to write and leave to us all.

A wonderful and insightful read.

0061714372|5.0|No doubt that Dave Mustaine is one of the most famous (and infamous) men in metal and in the music industry.  He's got some amazing stories to tell.  Of course you'd expect that, given he invented a whole genre of music.  In his book he certainly delivers great stories and history.  What's really refreshing is that this book provides a great deal of candid introspection along with those stories.  He even goes so far as to point out his *own* mistakes that precipitated his own exit from a band he helped create - Metallica.<br /><br />Those of you who are hoping for ammunition to defend Metallica in this book will be sorely disappointed.  If anything, people will probably have a renewed level of contempt for Lars Ulrich after reading this it (and in my opinion, rightfully so).<br /><br />Dave provides amazing detail of his upbringing, his life as a child, his discovering music.. and discovering various forms of self-medication to cope with his upbringing and childhood.  These all paint a picture that - while at times bleak -  also explains the drive behind his creative process and the source of inspiration for his lyrics.<br /><br />Now at this point you could say that the book sounds like another \\"don't let this happen to you\\" story.  Well, maybe in some ways - and I'm sure Dave would be glad if it kept at least ONE person from going down the path he did.  I think the difference is that, at the core of all of the insanity around him, there was still a basic sense of decency that was instilled in him.  So as he grew personally and spiritually, and learned to be more introspective, you see the person who continues to deliver in the music business time and time again.<br /><br />Dave talks also very candidly about his conversion to Christianity - very much a 'full circle' story given his beginning as Lutheran-baptized Jehovah's Witness (ugh.. talk about craziness).  He acknowledges that this, along with his wife, Pam, and his family, gave him the strength to find in himself the will to fight and get over addiction once and for all.  Without her I seriously do not think he would have survived as long as he has.  Talk about a woman with amazing strength.<br /><br />A great read that I couldn't put down once I started.<br /><br />And Dave, don't worry about the Rock 'n Roll Hall of Fame. B0011ZNAIC|4.0|The DreamWorks Animation formula, as witnessed in potent franchises like Shrek and Kung-Fu Panda works on the tried and true notion of dazzling children with cute visuals and slapstick action while entertaining the grown-ups with more intelligent humor and pop culture references.  Further tilting the scales in favor of the Bee Movie is that talking, personified animals rarely fail in this arena; add comedic legend Jerry Seinfeld to the fold and all signs point to yes!<br /><br />\\"Bee Movie,\\" directed by Simon J. Smith and Steve Hickner definitely leans to the adult side of the humor formula.  Make no mistake, the visuals are bright and crisp, there's no off-color content or situations, but the goofiness interjected in these films to keep the youngsters enthralled has been axed to make way for dryer humor that we older folk will surely enjoy.<br /><br />In fact considering that Jerry Seinfeld played a big part in this film's development, lends his voice and personality to the lead character, and has seen fit to include many of the costars from his hit television series, the type of humor within could best be compared to the logical/ observational type of comedy to expect here.<br /><br />The story follows one Barry B Benson (Seinfeld) and his best friend Adam Flayman (Mathew Broderick) graduate elementary, high school and college all within a matter of hours and find themselves on the cusp of adulthood, where, like all bees, it is time to choose which part of the honey-making process they'll be a part of for the rest of their short lives.<br /><br />Barry, it seems, doesn't jive with the hive way of thinking.  And rather than sign up for a singular job to last a lifetime, a trip outside the hive with the pollen jockeys opens Barry's peepers to a much larger world; namely the world of humans. A chance encounter with a bubbly florist named Vanessa (Ren&eacute;e Zellweger), Barry breaks the cardinal bee rule and speaks aloud to her! Yes that's right folks, all bees can openly communicate with us at any time but usually choose not to.<br />Long story short, Barry accompanies this human woman to the grocery store, discovers humans have stolen honey for bees and are selling it for a profit and decides then and there to put an end to the exploitation of bees by suing the human race.<br /><br />Traditional? Not exactly... But effective in a comedic sort of ridiculousness.  The film succeeds with a nice quick pace and characters that are easy to become concerned about.  Some of the lighter moments include cameos from a whole host of performers from Sting and Ray Liotta over to Larry King.  Chris Rock dazzles as the mosquito Mooseblood and even stars like Kathy Bates, Oprah Winfrey, and John Goodman manage to elevate what began as a clever little concept.<br /><br />In all I definitely enjoyed the Bee Movie and suspect I would have even if I wasn't a bit of a Seinfeld aficionado (why he couldn't write in parts for Jason Alexander and Michael Richards is truly beyond me).  The visuals do little to elevate the genre but they are clean and crisp in that \\"DreamWorks\\" kind of way and though the plot may drudge on a bit too much for the youngsters to endure, the older crowd will definitely not complain should the tikes request this one be put into the DVD player.but usually choose not to.   Long story short, Barry accompanies this human woman to the grocery store, discovers humans have stolen honey for bees and are selling it for a profit and decides then and there to put an end to the exploitation of bees by suing the human race. Chris Rock dazzles as the mosquito Mooseblood and even stars like Kathy Bates, Oprah Winfrey, and John Goodman manage to elevate what began as a clever little concept. 0439023513|1.0|Movie studios refuse to allow critics to see lousy movies before opening night, figuring that their inevitably negative reviews can only hurt ticket sales. Scholastic refused to send out copies of Mockingjay for review, a decision that correctly predicted the fact that this book is really lousy.<br /><br />Suzanne Collins had a good formula in The Hunger Games, and she repeated it almost exactly in the sequel, Catching Fire. However by the end of that book the districts were in open rebellion and many of the principals had been killed, which would seem to make it difficult for her to repeat the plot a third time in Mockingjay, the final book in the series.<br /><br />Have no fear, fans of The Hunger Games, Collins turned on the xerox machine a second time. The major difference between this book and its prequels is the color of the bookjacket (Spoiler Alert: Blue!). The first half of the book is devoted to Katniss Everdeen biting her lip, tossing and turning over whether to date Peeta or Gale, and trying on fabulous outfits. Her favorite designer was killed in the last book but, joyfully! it turns out he had secretly made a book of final designs for her before he was offed. The people of District 13, though impoverished to the point of never disposing of a piece of paper until both sides are thoroughly filled with text, have no trouble putting together the exotic materials needed for Katniss's couture.<br /><br />The plot of this volume deals largely with warfare, a war in which the districts band together to defeat the Capitol. However, Collins shares essentially none of this with us, instead we follow around Katniss and her film crew until on page 191, almost halfway through the book, somebody says \\"Good news is, the fighting's almost over in all of [the districts] but Two.\\" Virtually the entire war is reduced to a single sentence fragment.<br /><br />We have been told over and over again in the previous books, and again in the first half of this book, that the Capitol relies on the districts for food and other supplies. In this book we discover that they even get their own soldiers from District Two. Once the rebels have won all the districts (p.217), it would seem an easy enough to just starve the Capitol to surrender. That, however, would deprive Collins of her chance to throw Katniss back in an arena.<br /><br />Instead, the rebels decide on a frontal assault. Katniss goes though training, just as in the earlier books, she wears her special costume, as in the earlier books, designed by the same guy, and she is coached by Haymich, just as in the earlier books. In a war of magical lasers, hovercraft, and genetically modified lizard-dogs, she carries a bow & arrow, just as in the earlier books. Her team enters the Capitol, which has been boobytrapped to be just like the arenas of the Hunger Games and Catching Fire. There is even a dialog between her and Peeta repeated verbatim from the first book (p.321). It's all implausible and silly, and surprisingly boring. So many pages of teenaged angst; I am sure Jeanne d'Arc never whined like this.<br /><br />This book may be of interest to thirteen year old girls who find the 'Gale vs. Peeta' question fascinating, but I wouldn't recommend it to anybody else.food and other supplies. In this book we discover that they even get their own soldiers from District Two. Once the rebels have won all the districts (p.217), it would seem an easy enough to just starve the Capitol to surrender. That, however, would deprive Collins of her chance to throw Katniss back in an arena.    Instead, the rebels decide on a frontal assault. Katniss goes though training, just as in the earlier books, she wears her special costume, as in the earlier books, designed by the same guy, and she is coached by Haymich, just as in the earlier books. In a war of magical lasers, hovercraft, and genetically modified lizard-dogs, she carries a bow & arrow, just as in the earlier books. Her team enters the Capitol, which has been boobytrapped to be just like the arenas of the Hunger Games and Catching Fire. There is even a dialog between her and Peeta repeated verbatim from the first book (p.321). It's all implausible and silly, and surprisingly boring. So many pages of teenaged angst; I am sure Jeanne d'Arc never whined like this.    This book may be of interest to thirteen year old girls who find the 'Gale vs. Peeta' question fascinating, but I wouldn't recommend it to anybody else.

B0037QGS0A|3.0|The reason I rented this movie was because I admire Liam Neeson's and Julianne Moore's acting skills, and loved Amanda Seyfried's performance in Big Love and Mamma Mia! The plot of the story is predictable enough - a middle-aged couple played by Moore and Neeson are experiencing some strains in their marriage and their teenage son is totally self-absorbed. Then Moore mets Chloe (Seyfried) in the ladies' room whilst at dinner with her husband. The viewer senses an immediate connection and when Moore suspects her husband of cheating on her, she asks Chloe to seduce him to see his reaction. Well, Chloe plays along with this charade, and gives a blow-by-blow of her sexual encounters with Neeson's character, much to Moore's initial mortification and eventual turn-on (yes, apparently she gets off on hearing about their sexual exploits).<br /><br />The story then takes a dark turn (well, darker) when Chloe begins to get obsessed with Moore's character, an obsession which is reciprocated to a certain extent. There's some sexual encounters between both women which initially struck me as weird but then slowly began to make sense. Chloe is a complex character, in fact I think her character was the most complex of the three. There is definitely a hint of an abandonment complex, a sense of emptiness within Chloe which she feels can only be assuaged with Moore. The clue here is the hair pin which Chloe keeps and later presents to Moore as a gift. In the deleted scenes, there's more background information provided which enables the viewer to understand the motivations of the characters which I wish had been portrayed in the movie.<br /><br />The acting is wonderful as can be expected from two experienced actors and a talented up-and-coming actor. I just wish the storyline had been more credibly dealt with. Little things annoyed me too - the portrayal of Moore and Neeson's son as an accomplished pianist and also a hockey player? Not many pianists I know would risk their precious hands playing a potentially risky sport. That aside, there was also some awkwardness in the performance of the teen son. This could have been a complex, erotic thriller but it fell short to me.tentially risky sport. That aside, there was also some awkwardness in the performance of the teen son. This could have been a complex, erotic thriller but it fell short to me.
B0015DROBO|5.0|Larsson's ability to captivate the reader with wonderful character development and a dynamite story add up to a fantastic novel. Too bad he's not around to write more. Pulitzer Prize material.
B0019NB9A2|5.0|There is a discussion of the Blu-ray's quality following the required gush.<br /><br />If one had to list, oh, the 10 most-influential motion pictures, \\"Forbidden Planet\\" would be right up there with \\"Birth of a Nation\\", \\"Citizen Kane\\", and \\"Psycho\\". Its influence on popular science-fiction entertainment cannot be overestimated.<br /><br />The seeds of \\"Star Trek\\" are planted here, particularly the use of the ship's captain, executive officer, and surgeon as the principal players. So too is the conceit that the purpose of outer-space travel is to explore inner space -- the human condition. The desire to dress female space travelers in skimpy costumes isn't ignored, either.<br /><br />What makes \\"Forbidden Planet\\" such a standout is not that it was the first color science-fiction film (it wasn't), nor that it was the first \\"good\\" science-fiction film (\\"The Day the Earth Stood Still\\" and \\"Things to Come\\" come to mind), but rather the lavishness of the production and the unbridled imagination behind it. \\"Forbidden Planet\\" catches the viewer right from the start, with a nifty flying saucer and the greatest robot in movie history, in just the first 15 minutes. The visual effects (particularly of the ship passing behind Altair IV to produce an eclipse, and the surface of Altair IV) were state-of-the-art then, and more-convincing-than-not 54 years later.<br /><br />Also novel is the fact that the huge (for its time) $4M+ budget is in service of what is an intellectual story about whether man is basically good or evil, and whether we have the right to \\"play God\\". (\\"Forbidden Planet\\" owes a great deal to written science-fiction, and little to comic strips or previous films.) It's all dressed up with an ironic/sarcastic robot, and undressed-down with Anne Francis in mini-skirts that leave little to the imagination -- but \\"FP\\" is not the special-effects extravaganza we expect modern science-fiction films to be.<br /><br />This might explain why it's taken so long for \\"Forbidden Planet\\" to appear on Blu-ray, especially as there was an earlier HD-DVD edition. It appears Warners doesn't think there's much of a market for it. The local Fry's received only /one/ copy, which had not been sold when I walked in around 12:30PM on 9/7. One of the sous-managers told me that many Fry's hadn't received /any/ copies.<br /><br />\\"Modern\\" (hah!) audiences might also have problems with \\"Forbidden Planet\\"'s less-than-stellar acting (Walter Pidgeon is the only A-list actor). The best performance comes, not surprisingly, from Marvin Miller. His Robby deftly alternates among ironic/sarcastic {\\"It promotes rust.\\"), hurt (\\"Again?\\"), naive (\\"Stuff, sir?\\"), threatening (\\"Will you get in?\\"), and helpful (\\"May I be of service?\\").<br /><br />The script has more than its share of groaners. Though Cyril Hume (an American, not an Englishman), was a decent writer, he clearly failed to read the lines out loud as he wrote them, resulting in some unpleasantly clumsy dialog. (Walter Pidgeon wasn't a particularly good actor, but you can see him trying to improve some of the poorer lines.)<br /><br />Fred McLeod Wilcox's direction has the depth of tissue paper and the subtlety of a steam roller, though its general briskness helps a film that's more talk than action. Leslie Nielsen's delivery of the final line, in which he not only butchers the line, but practically swallows it, is wholly Wilcox's fault. Such poor delivery is (or was) common in American films, but this example is one of the very worst (\\"I see no enemy\\" in \\"Ben-Hur\\" being the other).<br /><br />\\"Forbidden Planet\\" has its problems, but any modern viewer who actually /enjoys/ the garbage turned out by modern film makers has no right to criticize. \\"Forbidden Planet\\" might not be \\"Amadeus\\" -- but it's /definitely/ not \\"There's Something About Mary\\".<br /><br />As for the Blu-ray edition... \\"Forbidden Planet\\" was shot on Eastmancolor, which, at that time, could not compete with Technicolor for sharpness or grain. (Technicolor had been abandoned at that point, anyhow.) Grain is sometimes visible, and the image is not as super-sharp as one might like. The transfer is from a composite negative, presumably the one used for the 50th-anniversary edition. As with that version, scenes with animation or static mattes show a significant drop in sharpness and color accuracy, and an increase in contrast. This is unavoidable, the price one pays for the rest of the film looking so good. I'd give it a B to B+ for HD image quality.<br /><br />There used to be a \\"real\\" stereo soundtrack for \\"Forbidden Planet\\", but the sound on this version appears to be panned mono. \\"Extras\\" include everything (I think) that came with the deluxe 50th-anniversary version (other than the metal box, lobby cards, and Robby figurine). These include the \\"sequel\\", \\"The Invisible Boy\\", an episode of the \\"The Thin Man\\" (which has a political twist surprising for its era), and several good \\"making of\\" featurettes. (For those interested, Anne Francis looks barely 56, let alone her actual 76.)<br /><br />Rush right out in a buying frenzy!not as super-sharp as one might like. The transfer is from a composite negative, presumably the one used for the 50th-anniversary edition. As with that version, scenes with animation or static mattes show a significant drop in sharpness and color accuracy, and an increase in contrast. This is unavoidable, the price one pays for the rest of the film looking so good. I'd give it a B to B+ for HD image quality.  There used to be a \\"real\\" stereo soundtrack for \\"Forbidden Planet\\", but the sound on this version appears to be panned mono. \\"Extras\\" include everything (I think) that came with the deluxe 50th-anniversary version (other than the metal box, lobby cards, and Robby figurine). These include the \\"sequel\\", \\"The Invisible Boy\\", an episode of the \\"The Thin Man\\" (which has a political twist surprising for its era), and several good \\"making of\\" featurettes. (For those interested, Anne Francis looks barely 56, let alone her actual 76.)  Rush right out in a buying frenzy!
0439023513|5.0|Fans of The Hunger Games will love the third and final installment, I know I did.  Continuation of earlier themes made it flow and read easily.  Like the first two books, Katniss is tortured by memories as well as current circumstances and torn between two loves.  The end provides resolution to this, but doesn't turn it into a \\"happily ever after\\", which was appropriate.  While I normally enjoy a fairytale ending, it wouldn't have felt right.  Let's say it ends with Katniss happier than she has been most of her life, which in itself feels like a miracle.
B003V4AK8E|4.0|I've got the FPS Freek thumbstick extensions fitted onto the Pro Elite (just like my 360 controller), and if you blindfolded me I really wouldn't be able to tell the difference (except for the textured grip and different PS3 d-pad on the Pro Elite). It may be a little lighter feeling than the 360 controller (but it doesn't have 2 AA batteries stuffed inside of it either, so this is probably the reason). Overall, it seems like a good deal for $35. The response of the thumbsticks feels just right--may be a little loose-feeling for some players; the sticks don't seem to provide as much resistance to pressure as the 360 controller thumbsticks [which I find a bit too tight], but it really doesn't seem to make too much of a difference (they simply don't require as much heave to move). Holding the Pro Elite side-by-side with the 360 controller, the size is big, comparable in thickness and width (I was expecting it to be smaller, but I'm glad it's not). The triggers are perhaps not as elongated as the 360, but they absolutely FEEL more like triggers than the original Dualshock, no question. The shoulder buttons are fine. It certainly fills the gap for those of us who own (and love) both consoles and know how seriously better the 360 controller is over the Dualshock. No flaming, just truth-saying.    Plugged in the dongle, didn't touch a thing, and the PS3 recognized the controller right away. My made-for-little-people-hands Dualshock is now sitting on the shelf. Goodbye. The Pro Elite turns the PS3 off no problem (but not on--you have to turn the console on manually first); it has sixaxis control; lighted buttons (who cares, but...). I'm sure eventually someone (maybe even Power A) will improve on third-party controllers for the PS3, but at this moment in time, this seems to be a perfectly fine solution--and a loooong time coming for those of us who care about such matters (and those of us who somehow sidestepped the Dreamgear Shadow 6 controller debacle). Now if only someone would make one with programmable buttons, but I guess I'm asking for too much.    #####################    EDIT #1: OK, so after a bit more intense play, the sticks do have a pretty big deadzone overall, I hate to say. I've got no other technical problems with the controller like others have. I don't spend time doing precision sniping online, just single campaign shooters against usually dumb AI, so I still prefer the feel of a 360 controller for the PS3, even if the deadzone means there's a learning curve / handicap to deal with. The textured grip is not smooth like the 360 of course, but it's not like picking up a box of needles, like some noisemakers seem to say here. Sounds to me like some of these players' hands are a bit on the...soft(?) side. But overall, yeah the deadzone business is going to take some getting used to, but I'll manage. It's worth it to avoid the cramped hand sensation of the too-tiny Dualshock.    ####################    EDIT #2: Finally had some FPS time with the controller (maybe about 10 hours) and wanted to add a quick update regarding the deadzone issue and regarding what some people call the \\"porcupine\\" textured grip. 1) For run-n-gun type scenarios (I've been revisiting games like Resistance 1 and 2, as well as Haze [playing coop campaign with a friend over LAN, which I never did first time around, and it is actually pretty fun]), the controller does seem to function fine. (Actually my coop partner and I both bought the controller, and they both work simultaneously in the same room--no frequency mixup/crossover problems or anything like that. However, his thumbsticks have had some sticking problems when pushed to the far left or right, but I've had no such problems--so the quality of the build seems to be a little hit and miss.) To clarify, I am NOT talking about super-precision sniping or anything like that though--strictly in fast-strafing scenarios (as well as down-the-iron-sights shooting), you end up compensating for the deadzone pretty quickly. Honestly, after 10 hours I am not noticing the deadzone in game at all; it feels pretty much like a 360 controller. (Reminder: I am using the FPS Freek thumbstick extenders on the Pro Elite controller, which I think helps with the deadzone issue a bit.) But again, this is not hair-trigger precision sniping stuff--but strictly run-n-gun. 2) Those who are complaining about their hands being permanently bruised by the textured grip on this controller are whining babies, or they have some rare brittle-skin disease or they are holding their controller like a freaking vice. In other words, the textured grip is neither here nor there--it does not ruin the controller, but it doesn't really add anything to it either. It just is what it is. It's not smooth like the 360 controller, and this is probably why these \\"overly sensitive\\" players are whining. I'll probably continue using the controller, but I've also recently invested in a wired 360 controller and the XCM Cross Battle Adapter 2.0, which allows use of an actual wired (not wireless) 360 controller on the PS3 with the added function of being able to reassign any button and the triggers/bumpers (and it also supports sixaxis motion control through the funky use of another switch on the adapter and assigning one of your thumbsticks to do the sixaxis stuff--not a permamnent solution, but at least it's there). It's a pricey investment (the XCM adapter costs about $75 itself, ugh) and requires a wired controller. I know nothing about deadzone/lag issue with this setup either (I understand there may be some lag problems), so I'll check in again for a little comparison after some playtime. But I hated the button layout on games like Killzone 2 (though I did finish that game as-is), and I wanted to see how being able to reassign buttons would improve my game. OK, now I'm rambling.    ##################    EDIT #3: I promised I would come back and discuss the XCM Cross Battle Adapter 2.0 and a WIRED 360 controller on the PS3. I just reviewed the XCM product here on Amazon (look it up), but here's the gist (it's all good news): After some limited use, if you can stand using a wired 360 controller, this setup FAR EXCEEDS any of the third-party wireless PS3 controllers I've attempted to use. There is no deadzone, and there is no lag. (If there is any lag, it is so microscopic I am unable to detect it. Some overly sensitive-types might believe they can detect a lag, but I think these folks might be imaging things). The button remapping is super simple. And the XCM DOES actually support six-axis motion control through the use of a switch (since, of course, the 360 controller has no motion control). It might not be a great solution, but at least it's there. Here's how the six-axis works: Hitting a switch on the adapter, you can assign the six-axis function to either the left or right thumbstick. BUT of course, whichever stick you use will lose its normal function (until you hit the adapter's sixaxis switch to off again). So, this is only a temporary solution--in other words, if you play a game that at times requires sixaxis (like in Killzone 2 when you have to turn a valve by tilting the whole controller left to right), you need to have the adapter near you, hit the switch, use the thumbstick by moving it left to right, then hit the adapter switch again to use your thumbstick normally. Not that big a deal, unless you are playing a game requiring a lot of sixaxis stuff. In a case like this, I could see this becoming an irritation if you had to do it a lot. The adapter also has a rapid fire function which I have not tried and probably will not use.     Honestly it was a chunk of change---all told, $75 for the adapter and another $25 or so for a wired controller---and this amount might be why it seems many people shy away from this setup. I can't blame them. But I have to say, having this VERY responsive 360 controller (that I can totally customize, yay, and again as far as I cantell, there is no discernable lag and absolutely no deadzone at all--after all, it's simply a wired 360 controller, so there would be no actual deadzone anyway) plugged into my PS3 makes me a happy gamer. Totally recommended if you've got the cashola.     (Oh, and since I'm so anal retentive about my gaming, I actually opened an old PS2 controller I had, removed/shaved down the triangle/circle/square/x buttons (same size as the Dualshock 3 buttons), cracked open the wired 360 controller and removed the A/B/X/Y buttons, and put the PS3 action buttons into the 360 controller, so the shapes match with on-screen context-sensitive button presses. Doing this is possible and takes an Xacto knife, some epoxy, and a little time. Totally doable. So, the wired 360 controller I am using with the XCM adapter actually has the PS3 action buttons in it. Heaven.) Think I'm going to sell my Pro Elite now. There's really no need to keep it...yay!
B00164KYV4|5.0|It's hard to make a movie as good as the book, especially \\"He's Just Not That into You\\" by Greg Behrendt and Liz Tuccillo. However; director Ken Kwapis did a great job creating a more personalized and emotional stories!<br /><br />We impetuous humans view relationships as an exception to all the common sense rules especially when we fall in love. The funny part is that we do it every time thinking that this time is somehow completely different. We continue to over analyze and complicate the obvious: If somebody is into us, they will simply show it! Clearly it is less science than we all might imagine and very given to our acquired delusions.<br /><br />Something must be said about clever movies that use jokes and laughter to present complex and confusing subjects like love, relationships, and humans' infinite stupidity! This is a great and smart movie that is worth every minute!
0451219597|1.0|I have to say this is probably one of the worst books I have read in recent years. I described it when asked by a friend as an Enid Blyton book for grown ups, it just needed a few \\"jolly good wheezes\\" in it to round off the general effect. The plot was totally implausible from beginning to end, and by half way through I did not care what happened to any of the characters, nor quite frankly what would happen at the end of the book.    The torture and interrogation of captured and or arrested resistance or allied forces was beyond credulity, that an important member of the resistance would divulge all she knew simply to save the embarrassment of wetting herself because she was not allowed to the toilet, was laughable, as were some of the other inventive tortures that can only be described as deviant.    That \\"The Jackdaws\\" themselves were recruited in less than 24 Hours for such an important mission from a bunch of transvestites and misfits was also comical. Do yourselves a favour and leave this book on the shelves of your local bookstore, or if you really must read it see if you can get my copy from where I left it on a Hong Kong Ferry.

0553805371|4.0|As other reviewers said, this book is a quick read of modern physics presented by geniuses. Their approach to explaining the historical progression of theories that lead to M Theory is quite entertaining. They thankfully leave out the math and stick to logic, leaving the beauty of the theories to shine through. Taken as a nice summary quantum physics primer the book is worth the read.    Unfortunately the authors make a fundamental mistake in declaring that free will is nothing more than the inability of scientists to do the calculations for the interactions of the thousand trillion trillion particles that make up a person. Apparently the authors' particles made them write this book without any choice in the matter. They want to reduce consciousness to mere biology. Too bad they rely on model-dependent realism - apparently subatomic interactions force us to create models as well. Their theory devolves into particle determinism, not realism. The Game of Life proves it! Yeah, right.    Philosophy as a profession is dead, but philosophy as a branch of knowledge is not. M Theory may explain the underlying physics of the universe but it has no ability to explain consciousness. The authors correctly arrive at atheism as truth, yet miss completely on free will and consciousness.
0743298039|5.0|Excellent book!  It took me a while to get through this book as life got in the way of my reading :)  However, this story was unique and beautiful.<br /><br />This is the story of a character's mysterious biography.  There are two narrators; the biographer and the biographee :)  The biographee is a writer herself and has never let anyone know the truth of her life's story.<br /><br />I'm sure others have already given a synopsis of the story, so I'll spare you the repetition.  This is a story that keeps the reader guessing at what will happen next.  Characters weave in and out of the story in such a way that you never know what is going to happen next.  Setterfield has a beautiful way of writing that I can't quite describe what I loved about it.  She gives details, but not so many that you get lost in the details and forget the story.  The characters are wonderfully written and you can get lost in them and their stories.<br /><br />I was drawn to this book because of the cover art (I know, I know, but I am a lover of books and can't help myself), the idea of a mysterious biography, the promise of ghosts (which the story isn't nearly as *ghostly* as one would think from the back cover) and reviews by others.  I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good fictional story, especially historical fiction.

B001ANUXUI|5.0|This is a review of the CD sound quality only. We already know how great of an album Who's Next is!    So I have at least three versions of this CD, including the rare MCA Ultimate MasterDisc gold edition. To my amazing surprise, this original 1984 issue is the best sounding of the lot! The new \\"remastered\\" deluxe edition is bloated and overly manipulated-- too loud which means it has been compressed and most likely peak limited during the mastering process.  The gold disc edition is okay but a bit disjointed. \\"Won't Get Fooled Again\\" also doesn't sound right on the gold disc. There seems to be digital noise or distortion in the middle register which affects the guitars and vocals during louder passages in this song. It's almost like the sound engineer feel asleep towards the end of the project. A true shame since the rest of the release isn't too bad.    Now, this 1984 edition is sonically fantastic! It has a lot of dynamics and breath. There's  an inherent warmth in the sound that you can only find on vinyl. No distracting distortion or \\"tingy\\" digital treble. The bass is well rounded and instruments are sharp and defined. Why does this version sound so much better than later iterations? Here's a tidbit I only found out after several years of owning this CD: this version was remastered by none other than legendary mastering guru Steve Hoffman. His DNA is all over this. If you are a big fan of the sound he was able to get from the gold discs he remastered for DCC and Audio Fidelity, you must grab this copy! Amazon.com may not list the serial number but just to make sure you have the right copy, the Steve Hoffman remastered edition's serial number is MCAD-37217.
B00006AW2G|5.0|If this album were a living entity, it could only be a deranged unnatural abomination - a Frankenstein - such are it's deep contradictions. How so? Well, just consider the irreconcilable contrast between the two forms by which all the songs here can be divided. On the one hand we have the simple, rootsy, lo-fi charm of the countrified tunes \\"Love In Vain\\", \\"Country Honk\\", \\"Let It Bleed\\", and \\"You Got The Silver.\\" These are modest nods to the musical forms that first moved the pubescent Brits. And then, on the other hand - a very scarred and bloody hand - we have the full throttle, balls-to-the-walls, death taunting, bravado of \\"Gimme Shelter\\", \\"Live With Me\\", \\"Midnight Rambler\\", and \\"Monkey Man\\" - searing, slick, highly produced, modern marvels of mayhem.<br /><br />Sure, other bands, even other Stones albums, have their complementary moods, but on this disc the Bad Boys really pushed the the two sides as far apart as anyone ever had. Then, to boot, they did themselves one better. Of course, I'm referring to the sublime gritty splendor that is the majestic closer to this unholy union of the sacred and the profane, the soaring classic \\"You Can't Always Get What You Want.\\" On this number they manage to not only gorgeously unite the two opposing aspects of this album but also dare to sum up the history of rock music, as it was at that moment, in a gloriously grand orchestration of all of their most profound influences. The resulting creation, a miraculously thrilling gospel epic, is at once as emphatically, absurdly overblown and melodramatic as any self possessed egomaniac could dare, while simultaneously being as humble and sincere as a farm hand's lament.<br /><br />The value of this atrocious unity, this mad marriage, is how spectacularly it reflects the American Experience. With their 3,000 miles of perspective, the Stones were uniquely positioned to construct a remarkable mirror to reflect the impossible, the irreconcilable, the tragic divisions that marked the US culture. It's a diagnosis of our collective mental fracture set to guitar and piano and tears. No one has since come anywhere near the perfection of this performance, this monstrously divided, monumentally sick masterpiece.s a diagnosis of our collective mental fracture set to guitar and piano and tears. No one has since come anywhere near the perfection of this performance, this monstrously divided, monumentally sick masterpiece.
B000002OXU|3.0|This is a review of the sound quality of the MCA Ultimate Master Gold Disc edition only. The album itself is a solid 5-stars.    The remastered job of this very hard to find (and expensive) gold disc edition of Who's Next is a disappointment. I have at least three versions of this CD. To my amazing surprise, the original 1984 issue is the best sounding of the lot!  This gold disc edition is okay but a bit disjointed. \\"Won't Get Fooled Again\\" also doesn't sound right. There seems to be digital noise or distortion in the middle register which affects the guitars and vocals during louder passages in this song. This is not present in other versions. It's almost like the sound engineer feel asleep towards the end of the project. A true shame since the rest of the release isn't too bad.    For my money, you must get the original 1984 CD pressing which was mastered by mastering guru Steve Hoffman. If you are a big fan of the sound he was able to get from the gold discs he remastered for DCC and Audio Fidelity, you must grab a copy of the 1984 version. Amazon.com may not list the serial number but just to make sure you have the right copy, the Steve Hoffman remastered edition's serial number is MCAD-37217. He's uncredited on the CD sleeve. Good luck and happy shopping!

I had the same reaction to this book that I had to Harold Marcuse's Legacies of Dachau.  This novel will not improve relations between Muslims and the west as western freedoms will not allow women to be treated as they are in this tale of absolute control.

0765326353|5.0|I must first admit that I am a fan of Brandon Sanderson's previous works and began reading his newest novel with some high expectations.  These expectations were well met.  The Way of Kings sets the scene for a coming battle of good versus evil that, while commonplace in the fantasy genre, is made unique through rich world building and in depth character development.  The world of the novel is expertly constructed and the details (cultural, religious, and environmental) attest to Sanderson's years spent developing the world.  Of particular note is the environmental landscape and geography of the world.  Massive storms rip through the landscape originating from a point deep in an unknown ocean in the East.  Yet they have natural characteristics in that the storms diminish over distance and are even blocked by a mountain range far in the west of the world's main continent.  The animals and plants to the far east (near the storm's origins) then have evolved to adapt to the pressures created by them (Sanderson does not use the term but it is clearly the case).  Instead of large mammals being commonplace, arthropods have become dominant and are present in their niches (like that of a dog, or oxen) because their shells provide protection during the storms.  The plants have similarly adapted over time to be able to withstand the storms.  In the far west these pressures do not exist, and grasses do not hide in the ground and plants that would flourish without the storms (an example from the book is strawberries) are still present there.   All of this world building alone almost makes the novel worth buying.  Yet Sanderson compliments it with realistic and complex characters that are put through extraordinary circumstances which change them as the story develops.  The philosophy presented through the characters is also quite detailed and the present of a smart and competent atheist (Gasp) was something that was very unique.  I must end this review with a positive nod to themysteries that are still present at the end of this first chapter of The Stormlight Archive.  These are numerous and deep enough that I will be reading the book again just to pry out any clues I might have missed while waiting for the next book in the series.
B0019NB9A2|5.0|The Blu-ray transfer,etc. is simply \\"OUTSTANDING\\".  This movie was made in 1956 without CGI and 2,000 people making it all happen.   And yet this movie was way ahead of it's time. Many movies that followed used this movie as a blueprint on how to make a GOOD Sci-Fi movie.  5 stars plus.  A must see.
0374158460|5.0|Warning: some readers may find some scenes pornographic. In other words, Jonathan Franzen doesn't necessarily take his readers to the edge, he actually tosses us over. And that is wonderful! This has to be one of the most amazingly conceived and written novels of the early 21st century, one that out Updikes Updike, that challenges Faulkner's place in the literary world as the master of the sentence that seems never to end. See page 191 which will require you to move to 192. But take in a big dosage of oxygen. It is one hell of a delicious sentence, one of thousands in this thick satire.<br /> Some of you may have already met the Berglunds--and let me state this: the Berglunds are the new Rabbit--in a Franzen \\"New Yorker\\" story that appears at the beginning of this novel. Walter and Patty. Lovely people living in lovely Minnesota. And with two lovely children: Jessica and Joey. Patty, of course, is the perfect mom who stays home and bakes the best-ever cookies while Walter earns enough money to keep their lovely lives running smoothly along with the Volvo. All this, of course, back a few decades. And next door is Carol--one of those unwed mothers--and Connie who spends most of her out-of-school time being mothered by Patty. Carol's house needs a lot of attention as does Carol. And soon she will be getting it from her newest boyfriend, Blake, who... Well, enough of that except for this. Patty was a college jock from a White Plains, New York, politically liberal family. And Patty has never fit in. So that is one reason moving to good old Minnesota has such appeal, more appeal actually than her not-so-much-attracted-to Walter who, by the way, has a buddy, Richard. Richard the cynic plays a very large role in this novel and is a totally wonderful contrast to Walter. Richard, by the way, rises to international stardom with his many bands and the songs he writes. Walter and Richard share similar views about the state of the planet: progressive ones. At least until... But, enough... I don't want to be telling you too much, do I!<br /> This is the satire you have been waiting for if you, like me, have been hunting for an alternative planet to move to now that the \\"Tea Party\\" has taken over, the icing on the Bush-Cheney cake! You see the kids grow up as all kids do. And they leave home. And opportunities knock for Walter, the do-gooder. But poor, poor Patty. What is a stay-at-home mom to do when the son moves next door to bed down with Connie? When Jessica sees through her mother's shallowness and goes her own separate way. What is she to do but write her autobiography. And that is a big section of this brilliant novel told in a truly wonderful format.<br /> If ever there is the perfect example of point of view, it is this novel. The reader is brought into the heads of the cast--and that is where some readers might find themselves saying \\"TMI\\"--but all I can say to that is this: it only gets better and better. And for those reviewers who don't like the characters because there is little to redeem them, well, dust off your \\"Heidi\\" because Franzen presents us with the raw truth about who we have become. And it is shameful what we are. Shameful.<br /> Dust off a place for the Pulitzer, Jonathan Franzen.ough... I don't want to be telling you too much, do I! What is a stay-at-home mom to do when the son moves next door to bed down with Connie? When Jessica sees through her mother's shallowness and goes her own separate way. What is she to do but write her autobiography. And that is a big section of this brilliant novel told in a truly wonderful format.    If ever there is the perfect example of point of view, it is this novel. The reader is brought into the heads of the cast--and that is where some readers might find themselves saying \\"TMI\\"--but all I can say to that is this: it only gets better and better. And for those reviewers who don't like the characters because there is little to redeem them, well, dust off your \\"Heidi\\" because Franzen presents us with the raw truth about who we have become. And it is shameful what we are. Shameful.   Dust off a place for the Pulitzer, Jonathan Franzen.

1563890119|5.0|\\"The Sandman\\" was perhaps the single most-acclaimed series of the 90s. Originally conceived as a vehicle for reviving an old superhero, it became a deciding factor in the creation of DC's \\"Vertigo\\" imprint, ran for seven years and 75 issues, made the New York Times Bestseller list, had numerous spin-offs, including \\"Lucifer,\\" which ran for 75 issues, and became a grand epic story and a tribute to human creativity. It even inspired the revival of said old superhero, in the form of \\"Sandman Mystery Theatre.\\"    \\"Preludes and Nocturnes\\" is not this book. It is a very, very good book, but it is not what solidified The Sandman as one of the greatest comics ever written. The early comics in Neil Gaiman's magnum opus do not have the same extended narrative focus as the later issues, and it is more of a horror comic than it is a poetic tribute to the human imagination. Nevertheless, \\"Preludes and Nocturnes\\" is highly imaginative, scary, and at times poignant.    \\"Sleep of the Just,\\" issue 1, is a bit confusing, giving us a somewhat bizarre story that, in a roundabout way, introduces us to Dream of the Endless and the main conflict of the story - he is imprisoned by a group of occult magicians who seek to capture death, and they steal his tools. It also serves to set up events in future books.    Issue 2, \\"Imperfect Hosts,\\" has Dream returning to his realm, which has fallen into a state of disrepair. The last page, I feel, is one of the books highlights.    \\"Dream a Little Dream of Me\\" brings us a crossover with John Constantine, of \\"Swamp Thing\\" and \\"Hellblazer\\" fame (two other famous Vertigo series). Having never read a John Constantine story, I feel his character was somewhat underutilized here.    \\"A Hope in Hell\\" is far more interesting than the previous issue, and introduces us to Lucifer, setting up the aforementioned spin-off comic. It contains one of the books other highlights, being a battle of wits between Dream and the demon who has his helmet. This book also introduces us to another plot element that is further explored in \\"The Doll's House\\" and \\"Season of Mists.\\"    \\"Passengers\\" is a more bizarre case. It sets up the primary antagonist of the next few issues, Dr. Destiny, an old and somewhat silly supervillain of the DCU. He is no longer silly. This issue is odd because of how much it stakes in the DC Universe. It features appearances from not only Dr. Destiny, but also Jonathan Crane (the \\"Scarecrow\\" of Batman fame), Scott Free (\\"Mister Miracle\\"), and the Martian Manhunter. Fans of DC will no doubt appreciate the references.    It's the last three issues where I feel this book really hits its stride - \\"24 Hours,\\" which is a work of pure horror, is one of the most disturbing things in this book's entire run, and one of the few works that Neil Gaiman said genuinely horrified him.     The next, \\"Sound and Fury,\\" gives us the climactic final showdown between Dr. Destiny and Dream. It wraps up the story arc and gives a satisfying conclusion. In earlier editions of the volume, this ended the book, but there has since been a change for the better.    The final issue included in this collection is quite a change of pace - \\"The Sound of Her Wings\\" introduces us to Death of the Endless, who is perhaps the most popular character in the entire series (she has three spin-offs books, one of which is oddly in the style of a Manga). Probably ties with Discworld for having the most popular version of the grim reaper to appear in fiction, likely due to the fact that Sandman's Death is not particularly grim. This story initially appeared in volume 2, \\"The Doll's House,\\" but it serves better here, as \\"The Doll's House\\" is already a better book than \\"Preludes and Nocturnes,\\" it has more relevance to the first book, and its omission from \\"The Doll's House\\" keeps the book from opening with two comics that have nothing to do with its main arc. Despite the subject, this is no doubt the lightest story in the book, which starts to set up the series as more of a dark fantasy than a horror, as earlier issues indicate. It's certainly a good note to end the collection on.    While \\"Preludes and Nocturnes\\" is not what The Sandman would eventually become, it has it's moments of inspiration, even in the earlier issues that don't quite mesh with each other, sometimes working better as individual issues than as a collected storyline (understandable, as these were the first issues).    I might not recommend this if you are only going to put a small number of comics in your library. If you want what solidified this series as a masterpiece, I'd recommend checking one of the later volumes. However, if you want to read the entire series, the very beginning is a very good place to start, and faulting the first volume for not living up to the others is a very small criticism.
B001UV4XFG|5.0|It was awesome!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Can't wait for Breaking Dawn to come out! They are going to be amazing! People should see this and all the other movies! But read the books also! they are different! But really good!
B002ZG980U|5.0|I have been reluctant to comment on Inception; there seemed little I  could add to the already extensive commentary. My initial sense was  that Inception, while it was a welcome relief to standard summer fare,  possessed enough flaws and precedents to render its claims to greatness  suspect. I gave it 8 stars over my first viewing and let it go at that.     Now, having watched Inception twice since then and having read the  screenplay (see the excellent, Inception: The Screenplay), I have  changed my mind. Inception is worthy of the praise given it. Without  reservation I now give it a 10. This is the first occasion in which I  have changed my verdict on a film following my initial viewing. Why?  Because Inception is easily the best film of the decade in terms of  sheer intelligence, the best film I would argue since The Truman Show.  Moreover, its plot of obsessive love, fear of falling, and frightening  dreams, makes it worthy of comparison to Vertigo. As good as Vertigo?  The fact that Inception can be mentioned without blanching in the same  sentence with Hitchcock's masterpiece tells you something.     I came to love the movie but I was desperate to say something new. I  wanted to comment on the richness of the world of Inception, and give   the viewer a bit more of an understanding of what underlies it.     In the near future, a drug has been discovered that enables people to  share a common dream. Viewed by many as a fascinating opportunity for  creativity, one danger is that a dreamer's mind can be invaded by an  intruder and unless the victim has been trained to resist these  \\"extractor(s),\\" he can be tricked into revealing his innermost secrets  (visualized as being within a symbolic dream \\"safe\\"). The battle  between a trained mark and one or more skilled extractors can be  harrowing.     This technology can be described as a form of controlled lucid  dreaming. Until this discovery, all experience had been that lucid  dreams cannot be controlled; anythingcould happen. Since most people  have had them, you know what I mean. But using this drug and its  delivery system (termed PASIV in the screenplay book), lucid dreams can  be controlled. These shared lucid dreams, however, are still subject to  external conditions and the dreamer's own internal state.     Note: the idea of entering into people minds while they are dreaming is  not new. See the movie \\"Dreamscape (1984),\\" which has dream specialists  invading the mark, as protectors or attackers. But there are some  remarkable new angles in Inception's approach.     First, the dreams can be recursive. There can be dreams within dreams  within dreams, though at each additional level the dream state becomes  increasingly unstable, requiring the addition of powerful sedatives to  maintain control.     Second, the recursive levels cannot be extended indefinitely. They  terminate in a state called \\"Limbo,\\" i.e. \\"unconstructed dreamspace.\\"  Limbo may be infinite in expanse. Little is known of it, though  according to the movie's math, time moves roughly 8000 times faster in  Limbo relative to reality.     Third, the minds of the participants, particularly if there is an  emotional involvement between them, can find their dream \\"waves\\" have  become blended or entangled.    There are profound metaphysical dangers in this, ontological and  psychological. Foremost is the loss of one's sense of what is real,  over time being increasingly unable to distinguish between the dream  state and reality. Then there is the loss of one's sense of self. Where  the dreamers are emotionally involved, e.g. in love, their minds can  begin to merge to such an extent that it is a difficult for them to  determine where \\"I\\" begins and the other takes over, who is dreaming  what in other words. There are mechanisms, \\"totems\\" for keeping track  of where one is in these dream spaces, but the problem is unsolved.    Into this world strides Dom Cobb, one of the best \\"extractors,\\" a  disturbed, troubled man, with overwhelming feelings of guilt towards is  dead wife, Mal. Cobb is desperately seeking an escape, and return home  to the only happiness he has ever known.     Inception is strikingly original not only in that it introduces a new  technology but a new terminology as well. A shoe-in for multiple  nominations, it is brilliantly edited with a superb score,  special-effects, and a wonderfully, attractive and likable cast.  Nolan's meticulous screenplay pursues its sober and somber plot (you  may smile/chuckle a few times but that is it) with grace and  high-intelligence.    I wish I could sum up the meaning of the movie, but I can't. One  possibility is that Inception is an allegory of the movie experience, a  dream of movies if you will. There is a strong overlap in what Cobb and  his team are pursuing with the movie experience itself as a shared  dream in which we share our emotional secrets. Nolan plays on this, but  the idea of a movie as reflexive of and subversive to one's life has  been often done and it is unclear if Inception adds much.     Another is that Inception should be taken as a movie of dreams, i.e. on  its own terms; that it works best if one simply accepts what is being  shown on the screen and goes with it. Admittedly, for most, multiple  viewings will be required to enable them to get to the heart of the  movie's emotions but they will be amply rewarded if they do. The  central vision in Inception of life's tragedy is compelling. Whether in  the dream state or in reality, we cannot escape ourselves and it is  impossible to tell if the happiness we have is real or an illusion.
B0000004F9|5.0|Like many of Soft Machine's utterly-rabid fans, I've spent the last forty years kowtowing to the Holy Grail of the 3rd album, while also greatly enjoying these two as brilliant development albums. (Also like many rabid fans, I quite rightly ignore anything made after Wyatt left.)<br /><br />But recently, while listening to an enormous playlist that shuffled randomly, a couple of these tracks came up, and they were utterly jarring and incomplete, out of context.<br /><br />So I deleted them, dusted off the CDs, and re-ripped each side as a single track. Truth is: each \\"track\\" was artificially and randomly named. To quote: \\"Acting on a recommendation from Zappa, the band split the main tracks into smaller pieces that were given arbitrary names taken from sound effect tapes in the studio.\\" (The naming convention they came up with is just utterly Soft Machine, ain't it?)<br /><br />When restricted to listening to each side as a single composition, they move to equal stature with the Mighty Third album. Sure: \\"But as I'm not, and of course I don't, and as I'm free, white and twenty-one\\" doesn't quite match the simple lyricism of: \\"Oh but I miss the rain, ticky-tacky-ticky\\", but all the same genius, the joy, the conflict (this was never a happy band) is there in full. And as I'm writing this, I'm currently listening to \\"Moon in June\\", but of course just to make sure I got \\"ticky-tacky-ticky\\" correct :-)

B001TW68P4|4.0|I discovered The Turtles (who eventually evolved into the group Flo and Eddie) last year, and have since come to see them as an incredibly underrated band.  It seems few people who didn't live through the 60s (I myself did not) have even heard of them.  The Turtles had only a few hits that remain well-known today.  I suspect that most people have heard \\"Happy Together\\" and perhaps even \\"Elenore,\\" but there are plenty of songs on here that were once very popular (for example, \\"It Ain't Me Babe\\" hit #8 in 1965, but isn't particularly well-known anymore).  But while I would not rate them on the level of, say, The Rolling Stones, as far as artistic merit, I do like them just as much, and I find it a pity that they have been so forgotten.          If you haven't heard of them, you should really give them a shot.  The rhythms are infectious, the vocals are impressive--Kaylan has a fantastic rock n' roll growl--and the melodies are frequently quite beautiful.  To be honest, the lyrics are rarely notable, though \\"Me About You\\" is a beautiful exception.  I could listen to that one all day.          If you are familiar with The Turtles, chances are you will be pleased with this collection, which includes their more well-known songs, like \\"Happy Together,\\" and some lesser-known ones, like \\"Outside Chance.\\"  You might also appreciate the bonus track, which is a Camaro commercial.  It's quite catchy, actually. :)        As with any greatest hits album, this collection is lacking a few  The one omission of this collection is \\"Eve of Destruction,\\" originally a Barry McGuire song.  Yes, it's a political protest song about the turmoil of the 1960s and doesn't really fit in with the rest of the collection, which is incidentally love-themed, but it is very powerful, and I highly recommend that you check it out.        A few of the songs on this collection are just spectacular covers, rather than original performances, and some of them were written by outside songwriters.  \\"It Ain't Me, Babe\\" was originally Bob Dylan and was also covered by Johnny Cash, but listen to a few versions and see who does it best; I know who my choice is.  If you're a purist, this might bother you.  However, the group can't really be judged for performing other people's stuff--keep in mind that this was a natural and accepted practice for even the most legitimate bands until The Beatles came along and revolutionized the rock industry.

But the film's biggest asset, besides the many deliciously laughed out moments(unintentional, of course), is its star, Miss Berkley,  bless her heart. And that's exactly why her performance, as the film itself, is a must-see.  Moreover, the extra features on this Fully Exposed DVD edition (the one minus the complementary accessories) even includes the famed commentary by witty man and \\"Showgirls\\" devotee David Schmader.  You'll giggle so much over the massive movie cheesiness that you'll want to repeat the experience again and again. B002ZRPQ5K|2.0|First of all I AM A HUGE KEANE FAN!!!! 0374158460|5.0|Jonathan Franzen's new novel, like his last novel The Corrections, has already garnered a great deal of hype. As was the case with that book, this novel is certainly worthy of the hype. Franzen will no doubt be remembered as of the great novelists of this age of American literature. I will begin by stating that I felt The Corrections to be better overall; however, this is certainly a great novel and is well worth the reader's time. I was particularly intrigued by the opening which essentially revels much of what is to take place in the book in regard to the Berglund's; this opening brings to mind the opening of William Faulkner's Absalom, Absalom!, as it does the same. Faulkner was interested in exploring egregiously dysfunction families in many of his works; Jonathan Franzen has proven himself to be interested in this concept as well. He expertly paints a portrait of the characteristics and idiosyncrasies of this family, and charts their attempt to become better people while attempting to effect a meaningful existence.       This novel also deals heavily with the American politics of the 2000's, with a particular emphasis on environmental concerns. Franzen meditates upon these issues without becoming turgid or pontificating. The novel is primarily interested in the ways in which these political times affect the characters and influence their lives. By doing this, Franzen provides a telling portrait of what it was like to exist in America during this previous decade. The character development is the strongest feature of this novel; it has been some time since a have felt so connected to a novel's characters. Franzen displays as much acumen in regard to the ways in which the human psyche functions as he does with turbulent contemporary politics. The main thing that one can grasp from these characters is that they are deeply estranged from others. This is due to a variety of issues: pursuit of abstract ideals, narcissistic inwardness, blind ambition, and so on. Itbecomes clear that they wish connect with others in their lives by forgiving them their idiosyncrasies and become better people. A great deal of the novel deals with these characters' attempts to accomplish this goal. These characters are not perfect and are certainly not heroes, they are instead human. Franzen has constructed a novel that is pedagogical, eloquent, accessible, and compelling in equal measure, thus making it certain that this is a novel that will be remembered.

B003T0G9XU|4.0|Tiffany Aching is the witch of Chalk, which means that she has to do all the messy rural stuff that witches do. But witches aren't always as appreciated as they should be, and Terry Pratchett's \\"I Shall Wear Midnight\\" flings the sensible young girl -- and the Nac Mac Feegles -- against a threat that really, really doesn't like witches.<br /><br />Tiffany is doing the usual witchy rounds in Chalk -- nursing the sick, burying the dead, watching cheese races, and rescuing the occasional girl from an abusive father. Then the local Duke expires after a long illness, and it's up to Tiffany to tell his son Roland and his \\"watercolour-painting wife-to-be\\" about what happened.<br /><br />The problem is, she's being stalked by a creepy eyeless man with a vile psychic stench, who is inspiring people to hate and distrust witches. Suddenly stones are being thrown, accusations are being made, and Tiffany even finds herself in the Ankh-Morpork jail. And if Tiffany doesn't find a way to stop the Cunning Man, things will get very toasty for the witches...<br /><br />Due to having Alzheimer's disease, Terry Pratchett had to dictate \\"I Shall Wear Midnight\\" instead of the usual computer typing. As a result, the book's beginning is very rambly and scattered, as if Pratchett hadn't fully thought out how the plot was going to go -- but after the Duke's death, things start to tighten up and move faster.<br /><br />And Pratchett hasn't lost any of his delicious wit, whether it's poking fun at cliches (the cackle box!) or sharp dialogue (\\"Have you boys got no shame?\\" \\"I couldnae say, but if we have, it probably belonged tae somebody else\\"), or his knack for writing truly chilling moments, such as Tiffany seeing the Cunning Man's holes-where-his-eyes-should-be.<br /><br />But unlike authors who talk down to \\"young readers,\\" Pratchett doesn't shy away from realistically dark moments, like Tiffany caring for a girl who was badly beaten by her father until she miscarried. These parts -- and the \\"rough music\\" -- are more horrifying than the Cunning Man.<br /><br />Tiffany herself is a very realistic depiction of a sensible, mature, no-nonsense young lady (like a younger version of Granny Weatherwax). While Pratchett occasionally reminds us that she IS still young (and prone to little stabs of jealousy), she grows up a great deal in this book. And there are some hints of romance with a young guard (who can pronounce the word \\"marvelous\\").<br /><br />\\"I Shall Wear Midnight\\" is another excellent entry in Terry Pratchett's Tiffany Aching series. It starts out rather slow, but soon kicks into stride.than the Cunning Man.
